SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Norman McDonald
Address: Wapella
Birthplace: Saskatoon

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1900
Where did you set up housekeeping? In 1900 when I moved here
Where had you been living before that? Right here with my father and mother
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
How far was it to your nearest store? About 2 miles in summer house
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a month or so
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Sugar, soda, baking powder and fish

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Ogilvie Flour
In what quantities did you buy it? Two & three bags at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 37-3/4 dollars
How much did you use graham flour? ...........................................
Whole wheat flour? ...............................................................
Was flour milled locally? Yes. How far away? 8 miles. What year? 1856
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Whole wheat flour
What other grain products did you use? ...........................................
Cornmeal? Yes. Whole Wheat? Yes. Farina? ...........................................
Other? ...............................................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? With a chipper
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? [1875]
Where did you set up housekeeping? [Napella, Sask.]
Where had you been living before that? [Napella, Sask.]
For how many people did you prepare meals? [6]
How far was it to your nearest store? [2 miles]
How often could a visit be made to the store? [Every 3-4 weeks]
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? [Sugar, salt, flour, butter, cooking powder, and fish]

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? [Canadian Flour]
In what quantities did you buy it? [20 lbs.]
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? [9.375¢]
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour? [Yes]
Was flour milled locally? [Yes]
How far away? [Saskatoon]
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? [Milled, local]
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? [Yes]
Whole wheat? [Yes]
Farina? [Yes]
Other? [Yes]
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
How did you grind it? [Hand mill]
3. SUGAR AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.50
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? None
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb.
At what price? I can't remember.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From cows.
Butter? Yes, made butter.
Eggs? We had no hens till 1886.
What was the price of butter? $1.25
Did you pack eggs for winter? No.
Did you make butter? Yes.
What kind of cheese? That was made in the nearby town.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Horse but rabbit meat.
How did you get fresh meat? In later years we used to kill a steer or hogs for ourselves.
How often did you get fresh meat? Every time we needed it.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.
If so, what year was it organized? 1915.
Did you use game? Yes.
For how long? 1883 to 1892.
What part did fish play in the family diet? In May 1889.
Has the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Sometimes we had salted fish.
Kinds? Pike and suckers.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Everything come wrapped in paper bags

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g. winter or summer.

In 1888
For breakfast Porridge, Bread & Butter, Tea
For Dinner Potatoes, some will game
Bread & Butter, Fish soup was much
about the same as we did not have any
baked dishes in those days. Ages 14, 16, 19
21, 12 my mother 60 yrs and mother 53 years

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1888
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

We had a couple of neighbors in with some
of these families. Their ages were all the way
from 10 years to 45 and there was one that
was 60 years. There were 12 of us altogether
our menu was roasted and fried Rabbit, Bread
& Butter, Potatoes, Tea with sugar and milk.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Never

May 1918

For breakfast: Pancakes, Bacon, Sausage, Coffee.

For dinner: Roast Beef, Potatoes, Gravy, Vegetables, Bread.

For supper: Biscuits, Butter, Jam, Coffee.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The meals were prepared the same way. But they did not have all the varieties that they have today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We have always made our own bread and are doing so still, and we don't buy but very little prepared food.
